data.question: What is the concentration of Cl in the lunar mantle?
What makes Cl unique in lunar samples compared to other isotopic systems?
data.answer: Its hydrophilic affinity and high volatility

data.question: Why would the extreme fractionations in lunar materials not have occurred if lunar basalts had initial H contents close to terrestrial magmas?
data.answer: Because terrestrial magmas have higher H contents, which would prevent the extreme fractionations observed in lunar materials

data.question: What suggests that the Moon was initially anhydrous?
data.answer: The suggestion that high H contents calculated for some lunar samples are atypical and the extreme volatile enrichment found only in anomalous samples

data.question: Is the adaptability of MOF porosity limited by the metal coordination geometry?
Does the flexible peptide linker in the crystalline porous solid play a pivotal role in changing pore conformation?
Are proteins characterized by an adaptable response to their environment due to the manifold torsions available to polypeptide chains?
What is the role of the dipeptide linker in the crystalline porous framework?
data.answer: It is arranged in a regular array by coordination to metal centers, enabling the available pore volume to evolve smoothly from zero as the guest loading increased

data.question: What does the observed cooperative feedback in sorption isotherms suggest about the energy landscape of the material?
data.answer: It suggests an energy landscape similar to that required for protein folding

data.question: Can the solvent in the crystalline porous solid be removed reversibly to give a desolvated material stable to 250Â°C?
Does the desolvated material sorb N2 at 77 or 195 K?
What happens to the sorption response of the desolvated material to CO2, MeOH, and water?
data.answer: It shows a different behavior with sigmoidal dependencies and gating above a temperature-dependent gate pressure

data.question: What does the Hill model describe in relation to the desorption isotherms?
data.answer: It describes the cooperative sorption of guests by the material just above the gate pressure

data.question: Is the adaptability of the porosity in the material limited by the degrees of freedom available to the linkers?
What does the presence of a transient tensile force induce in the gem-difluorocyclopropanes?
data.answer: It induces a net isomerization of the trans-gDFC into its less-stable cis isomer

data.question: Does the material combine preformed pores with the degrees of freedom from a peptide linker required for conformational selection?
What is the result of the counterintuitive response of the gDFC to a transient force of extension?
data.answer: The gDFC contracts in response to the transient force

data.question: Are the sorption isotherms of the material similar to the response of proteins undergoing conformational selection?
Does the material display adaptable porosity that evolves continuously from an open to a partially disordered closed structure in response to the level of guest loading?
Is the observed gating in sorption isotherms due to lattice expansion and polymorph switching in the material?
